As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, all gatherings are prohibited with a number of exceptions and restrictions:    Funerals – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  Religious services – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  Weddings – up to 4 including administrators  Cultural or traditional occasion – up to 16 people and no more than 2 hours  Meetings or workshops – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  All sports and recreational activities are suspended except national team events with no spectators.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, permits are required to travel between the 9 designated zonal regions of Botswana.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Botswana is divided into nine COVID-19 zones and the Government of Botswana has restricted the movement of people. You will need to apply for an interzonal travel permit to travel between zones. Travel within one of the nine COVID-19 zones, outside of the curfew times, does not require any special permissions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705074856/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, traveler are permitted but they are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test valid within 72 hours of their departure for Botswana. Travelers entering Botswana from high risk countries may be required to quarantine at a designated facility and will be tested on day seven of their quarantine to be released based on the results of the test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

You must present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test performed no more than 72 hours prior to your arrival. After arrival, you will have to remain in contact with the local health authority for a period of 14 days for self-monitoring.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210705074923/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/entry-requirements

As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, antigen tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings and testing centers around Botswana, and PCR tests are available at specific hospitals, laboratories, and lodges. Tests are readily available and are to be paid for by the patient.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 Testing:  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Botswana? Yes  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  •	Antigen (rapid) tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings and testing centers around Botswana. They are readily available and affordable.  •	PCR tests are available for U.S. citizens at various locations including (not exhaustive):  •	Sir Ketumile Masire Teaching Hospital and Diagnofirm Medical Laboratories, both in Gaborone.  •	Some Okavango Delta lodges and camps and some Chobe National Park lodges and camps can fly in a licensed practitioner to conduct the tests. These tests cost from $330 to $450 per person and results take from 8-48 hours depending on urgency.  •	Diagnofirm operates PCR testing in Maun at around 950 BWP.  •	Okavango Air Rescue in Maun offers antigen testing from 125 to 180 BWP.    •	*Teaching Hospital PCR tests are 500 BWP and results can be slower than 48-72 hours as this is the main testing facility for everyone in country and is cheaper than Diagnofirm. Diagnofirm offers PCR tests for around 850 BWP which are available in less than 24 hours, usually within 6-8 hours. Antigen tests are available at multiple locations around Gaborone and costs range from 150 to 500 BWP. All testing is paid for by the patient. The Teaching Hospital price of 500 BWP is a price limit set by the Government of Botswana and is therefore partially subsidized.  •	Test results are delivered by text message/SMS. Expect delays in messaging even if the results are completed on time.  •	Diagnofirm tests generate a certificate of the results that passengers can carry with them.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705075056/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, Oxford University-AstraZeneca, Moderna, Sinovac, and Pfizer BioNTech have been approved for use. Janssen (Johnson&Johnson) and Gamaleya (Sputnik V) may be used in Botswana in the coming months.     The rollout planned through COVAX will provide 100,800 vaccines for the country. 24,000 AstraZeneca doses have been delivered according to COVAX. Botswana announced the delivery of an additional 38,400 AstraZeneca doses from COVAX.  The Government of Botswana reports 30,000 Covishield vaccines from India were received in early March and 200,000 doses of Sinovac were delivered on April 25. 19,890 Pfizer doses were received through COVAX in early June.  Botswana began its vaccination campaign on March 26-7. They have opened vaccinations as of May 10 for those over 65, followed by those aged 55-64. They will prioritize those over 65 and those over 55 with underlying health conditions as more vaccines become available.  Persons over 18 may already register on the vaccine registration webpage for future availability as eligibility expands.  Government officials are being vaccinated, as confirmed on the government's Twitter.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613062420/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613053303/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor

Botswana announced the delivery of an additional 38,400 AstraZeneca doses from COVAX.  •	The Government of Botswana reports 30,000 Covishield vaccines from India were received in early March and 200,000 doses of Sinovac were delivered on April 25. 19,890 Pfizer doses were received through COVAX in early June.  •	Botswana began its vaccination campaign on March 26-7. Since April 19, 2020, the following measures have been adopted:  1. provision of water and electricity for a period of two months, free of charge  2. prohibition to evict renters in case of no payment of financial obligations from March to June 2020  3. suspension of VAT collection on the production and on the sales of basic goods.    web.archive.org/web/20210524162716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Country-Specific Information:    Curfew: The following provinces have a curfew in place from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am: Kinshasa, North Kivu, South Kivu, Kongo Central, Lualaba, Haut-Katanga. As of April 13, the curfew is lifted entirely in all other provinces.  Masks are required in public spaces.  Businesses, schools, airports, and ports are open. While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607113847/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607115101/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607115101/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus

Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required in public, including on public transportation and at all airports.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607113847/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Domestic travelers age 11 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel between the provinces when departing from Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, Goma, and Kisangani. Where possible, the test must be taken within 7 days of travel.  Check with your airline about COVID-19 safety measures, testing requirements, and health requirements at your destination.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607113847/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to the Republic of Congo  All passengers arriving in the Republic of Congo by commercial flights should provide proof of a negative coronavirus (COVID-19) test undertaken within 72 hours upon entry, with the exception of children under 11 years of age. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Passengers who do not present a negative COVID-19 test upon entry will undertake a COVID-19 test at the airport, and need to self-isolate for 14 days, pending the results.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607120246/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/entry-requirements

The Grand (Greater) Libreville area comprising of the three municipalities of Libreville, Owendo, Akanda and Ntoum is in confinement or lockdown. Travel in and out of the Grand Libreville area is prohibited. However, travel within Grand Libreville is permitted.  There is a daily curfew from 6pm to 5am.  Taxis are only permitted to carry up to three passengers.  Domestic flight restrictions have eased to allow two flights per airline per week. PCR tests no older than 7 days are required for residents of Gabon who wish to travel within the country.   https://archive.vn/pWyMx

The Gabonese government has extended the state of health emergency indefinitely. Domestic flight restrictions have eased to allow two flights per airline per week. The Grand (Greater) Libreville area comprising of the three municipalities of Libreville, Owendo, Akanda and Ntoum is in confinement or lockdown. Travel in and out of the Grand Libreville area is prohibited. However, travel within Grand Libreville is permitted. From 26 October, people holding a Laissez-Passer (a pass issued to people carrying out essential services during curfew hours) will have to renew this via a new internet platform laissezpassercovid19@gouv.ga. Taxis are only permitted to carry up to three passengers.  https://archive.vn/pWyMx

The Amended Budget Law approved in end-June 2020 proposed the control of non-priority expenditure and redirects savings and development partners support of FCFA 73.9 billion (USD 138.1 million or 0.83 percent of GDP) to COVID-19 related spending. The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays. The Minister of Finance has created a fund available at their Caisse de Depots et Consignation (CDC) and designated a public accountant in order to facilitate disbursements of the health-related spending of that fund.  https://archive.vn/P053S

Generally available. 2 vaccines: Gamaleya Sputnik V and Sinopharm (Beijing) BBIBP-CorV. Vaccine doses administered: 22,524, Fully vaccinated: 0.37%. Received at least one dose: 0.64% of population. As part of the implementation of the National Vaccination Plan, the Minister of Health, Dr Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong, accompanied by officials of the Copil-coronavirus Technical Commission  and the National Vaccination Committee, proceeded from 17 to May 23, 2021 , at the launch of phase 3 of the vaccination campaign inside the country. The launch of the vaccination in its phase 3 was preceded by the training of teams and the preparation of the vaccination centers by the experts of the National Vaccination Committee.  https://archive.vn/Z0viP  https://archive.vn/Pg97x  https://archive.vn/jnRD1

The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.  Social distancing and other hygiene requirements continue.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517175002/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

""All travelers must present evidence of having tested negative for COVID-19 using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours before arriving in the country. Travelers from countries where a new strain of the virus has been identified will be tested on arrival. These travelers face a mandatory quarantine, at personal expense, in a government facility pending a negative test. Travelers who test positive or do not provide the appropriate documents face quarantine for at least 14 days. Travelers arriving from hotspot countries, including US, UK, Nigeria, France, Japan, Singapore, South Africa, South Korea, Turkey, Sweden, India, and Pakistan, will be required to undergo a rapid COVID-19 test upon arrival.""   http://web.archive.org/web/20210621112253/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490211/gambia-covid-19-related-entry-measures-remain-largely-unchanged-nationwide-as-of-june-14-update-26

Across Kenya, the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30, with all in attendance expected to abide by Ministry of Health protocols. Passengers who have been present in India, Pakistan, or Bangladesh within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Liberia . Travelers from Nepal and Brazil are required to undergo quarantine at a government-approved facility at their own expense. They will be tested on the seventh day of isolation and released if the result is negative. All other incoming travelers must present a negative PCR COVID-19 test result upon arrival at the airport in Liberia regardless of vaccination status. According to UNESCO schools are fully open: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614073245/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse.   Schools and colleges are permitted to open on a rotational basis to reduce numbers on site and in school transport: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Supermarkets, grocery shops, hardware stores, cafes and clothing stores are permitted to operate normally but must observe COVID-19 Protocols on sanitisation and social distancing. Hair salons may operate an appointment-only service between 8am and 8pm. Off licenses can operate Monday to Friday between 8am and 8pm with take-out service only.  All over the counter essential service providers are permitted to operate with 50% maximum staff capacity. Digital payment methods are encouraged. Fuel stations may operate 24 hours.  Supermarkets, grocery shops, hardware stores, cafes and clothing stores are permitted to operate normally but must observe COVID-19 Protocols on sanitisation and social distancing. Hair salons may operate an appointment-only service between 8am and 8pm. Off licenses can operate Monday to Friday between 8am and 8pm with take-out service only.  All over the counter essential service providers are permitted to operate with 50% maximum staff capacity. Digital payment methods are encouraged. Fuel stations may operate 24 hours.  Textile and manufacturing industries can operate at 50% capacity for both a day and night shift. Other businesses, public and private institutions and NGOs may operate between 8am and 4pm with 50% of staff on rotation. Hotels and hotel restaurants may open at 100% capacity. Conferences and workshops can be held but numbers are restricted to 50% of the conference venue capacity. Restaurants and fast food outlets may operate with 50% seated capacity between 6am and 9pm. Covid-19 protocols must be observed (including sanitisation and social distancing). Alcohol is only permitted to be sold as take-out. Gyms may operate outside with not more than 100 people and must observe social distancing. The entertainment industry is permitted to operate with a maximum of 120 people inside and 500 people outside. Screening and registration at the entrance is mandatory. Staff must ensure that attendees observe COVID-19 protocols including wearing masks, sanitising hands and practicing social distancing. Event organisers may be arrested for non-compliance. Nightclubs remain closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
Political rallies and other gatherings are banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Church services are permitted indoors only and with numbers limited to 50% capacity of the church. The service should not last more than two hours and one hour must be allowed for disinfection between services. All people must wear masks all times, including when singing. Weddings are permitted with a maximum of 50 guests and a maximum length of 2 hours, and pre-packed food only. Funerals are restricted to a maximum of 50 family members and 10 attendants for a maximum of 2 hours. Only immediate family members may view the deceased at the mortuary. Night vigils and buffets are not permitted. Gyms may operate outside with not more than 100 people and must observe social distancing. Contact and non-contact sports are permitted with no spectators. Contact sports are only allowed with police permits and players and technical teams must be tested for COVID-19 prior to training camps. Social and family gatherings are not permitted. https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Public transport can now operate at full seated capacity. Masks must be worn at all times. Eating in the vehicle is prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
Lesotho is under “Blue Level” restrictions. A curfew is in place from 10pm to 4am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Anyone leaving their place of residence must wear a face covering. This includes while walking in the street, and in shops and public offices.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Lesotho received the first batch of AstraZeneca vaccines on 3 March 2021. The 36 000 doses enabled the government to roll out its mass vaccination programme a week later. King Letsie III and Prime Minister Moeketsi Majoro were among the first to vaccinated against the deadly virus which had infected 10 720 people and killed 316 by yesterday in Lesotho.  The vaccination campaign was then spread to essential workers such as health workers and media practitioners. The ministry also vaccinated the elderly and those with life-threatening conditions like HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis.  The latest donation will enable these groups to receive their second and final dose of the vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614074521/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106100503.html

Yes  •	Hospital Manarapenitra Andenatepenaka and IPM Avaradoha offer PCR tests for COVID-19. For IPM Avaradoha, the cost is 303,000 AR. You must bring your passport and a copy of your passport, visa, and ticket. Results are available in 24 hours electronically or by pickup. Their number is 020-22-401-64/65.  InstitutPasteur offers serological tests for COVID-19. Preliminary estimates suggest that around 95 percent of the planned COVID-19-related spending has been was committed or implemented in 2020. The government fully executed the support to electricity and water SOEs and the food distribution plans, and around 76 percent of COVID prevention and medical support spending. 100 percent of the household income support were committed but most transfers are only expected to be made in 2021 as potential beneficiaries are being identified. With the onset of the second wave of the pandemic, the transitional authorities re-introduced VAT exemption on utility bills for December 2020 and January 2021. The additional measures are estimated at around 0.03 percent of GDP. To provide further support to the economy and to strengthen medical capacity, new policy measures at around 0.9 percent of GDP have been budgeted for 2021, which includes medical spending related to COVID-19, support to companies and households.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210613115810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government has allowed international commercial passenger flights; however, inbound and outbound flights are limited.    All incoming travelers must present a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no longer than 72 hours before arrival.    Travelers arriving by land are required to present a negative COVID-19 test. This will be valid for 14 days for those who require multiple entries over a short period of time. This also remains valid for those who are leaving Mozambique for no longer than 14 days. Sea borders remain closed except for essential freight transport.    Passengers who test positive upon arrival in the country or fail to provide a negative test result must self-quarantine for 14 days. Those who provide a negative test result are exempt from the quarantine regulation.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210624174654/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466831/mozambique-authorities-maintain-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-april-14-update-13

Non-Mozambican citizens, including U.S. citizens, who have a valid DIRE (residence permit) and/or required visa(s) are able to enter Mozambique, subject to the COVID-19 testing requirement below, without seeking specific authorization from the Ministry of Interior.  Tourists: For travelers arriving for tourism purposes only, visas are available upon arrival with proof of a return ticket and hotel booking.  Travelers arriving in Mozambique will be required to provide proof of negative Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)-based COVID-19 test results administered in their country of origin within 72 hours of departure. Children up to age 11 are exempt from this requirement.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210701163416/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Due to rising COVID-19 cases in some neighbouring countries, the Malawi Government has taken the decision to only allow entry for returning Malawian citizens, residents and essential travellers.     From 26 April, Malawi banned all but essential travel to and from Bangladesh, India, Pakistan and Brazil. Entry to Malawi will not be granted to passengers who have been in these countries within the previous seven days. Those undertaking essential travel will be required to self-quarantine at designated hotel accommodation for 14 days on arrival at their own expense.    On 12 June Malawi introduced the following restrictions on entry at all borders. A person who: is not a citizen of Malawi; does not hold a resident permit for Malawi; does not have a permanent home or is not ordinarily resident in Malawi; is not part of a team of medical personnel that is required to provide medical services in Malawi; is not a member of the diplomatic or consular staff of a country that is accredited to Malawi or is in transit to another country; or is not a spouse, shall be refused entry into Malawi. Exceptions are made for members of an organisation intending to support, supporting or implementing any COVID-19 related intervention or drivers of a vehicle, cabin crew of an aircraft or vessel transporting essential goods.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621114815/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi

Emergency cash transfers to some households earlier on the pandemic, but no evidence that those have continued into 2021.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621123434/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621124019/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-malawi-economy-idUSKCN22A3GG

To support small and medium enterprises (SMEs), commercial banks and micro-finance institutions will be, on a case-by-case basis, restructuring SME loans and providing a moratorium on their debt service until end-June 2021. However, no evidence of debt/contract relief for individual households.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621123434/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy change. Covid-19 information and updates made available on government Facebook page.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621115041/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawigovernment%2F%3F__tn__%3D-UC%252AF

Malawi has open public testing, including for those who are asymptomatic. All tests are done for a fee. The average cost for a COVID-19 PCR test is approximately 37,500 MWK (46 USD ) for Malawian citizens and 75,000 MWK (92 USD) for foreign nationals. Face coverings advised in public.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621120155/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malawi/coronavirus

According to Malawi government authorities, as of April 6, 2021, the vaccination has been extended to everyone 18 years old and above.  However, only 400,000 out of Malawi's 18 million citizens--approximately 2% of the population--have been vaccinated (coding as a 2, as vaccination rate is significantly lower than 20% of the target population and it does not seem that all key workers, vulnerable groups, or elderly groups have been vaccinated). Vaccines: AstraZeneca    The low vaccination rate is due to vaccine shortages and vaccine hesitancy. Malawi received a total of 512,000 doses, 93% of which have been used. Thousands of expired doses have had to be destroyed. The country is expecting a donation of 900,000 doses from the COVAX facility by the end of July.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621120834/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/malawi-facing-covid-vaccine-shortage-after-burning-expired-doses    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621112953/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621121225/https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=~MWI
No evidence of specific policies regarding the protection of elderly people.
Prior to June 17, 2021, all schools were open with COVID monitoring and precautions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210619001402/https://neweralive.na/posts/schools-only-closed-in-locked-down-areas

As reported by Namibia's New Era newspaper, the Education Ministry of Namibia clarified on June 17, 2021 that in-person education would be suspended in three heavily-affected areas: Windhoek, Rehoboth and Okahandja, until the 30th of June. Schools in other areas are continuing in-person teaching with health regulations until the winter holiday beginning June 25th.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210619001402/https://neweralive.na/posts/schools-only-closed-in-locked-down-areas

In a New Era article, the Ministry previously directed that students and teachers in the heavily-affected regions of Windhoek, Rehoboth and Okahandja should stay home until July 26, 2021. There is no evidence of these schools having opened. An article on The Namibian suggests that other schools are open for in person teaching, but some are closing due to local Covid cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210619001402/https://neweralive.na/posts/schools-only-closed-in-locked-down-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704062604/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106170720.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704062631/https://www.namibian.com.na/102836/read/Oshakati-school-suspends--face-to-face-learning--again

Health precautions are required in all public spaces, including businesses where social distancing must be practiced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, as of June 16, 2021, businesses such as salons, beauty parlours, hairdressers, pools, spas, gyms, studios, and fitness centers are open with COVID precautions. Contact sports are banned and the sale of alcohol is restricted to 9:00 to 18:00 Monday through Friday.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, gambling houses, nightclubs, gyms and sports clubs, public recreational spaces including playgrounds and swimming pools are not permitted to operate. Sale and purchase of liquor from Shebeens and bars is restricted to 9am to 6pm Monday to Thursday on take-away basis only. On site consumption of liquor is prohibited, except at restaurants, guesthouses, hotels and similar establishments where guests reside and all food establishments are to serve food on a take-away basis only. Contact sports are currently banned and non contact sporting events may not have spectators.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, as of June 16, 2021, the number of attendees at?public gatherings?indoor and outdoor has been reduced to 10 people.?    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, the number of people permitted at public gatherings is 10 persons; and indoor public gatherings should not last longer than 2 hours. Registers of attendees must be maintained, temperature checks recorded, and hand sanitising facilities put in place. Face masks and social distancing of at least 2 metres are mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, as of June 16, 2021, the number of attendees at?public gatherings?indoor and outdoor has been reduced to 10 people.?    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, the number of people permitted at public gatherings is 10 persons; and indoor public gatherings should not last longer than 2 hours. Registers of attendees must be maintained, temperature checks recorded, and hand sanitising facilities put in place. Face masks and social distancing of at least 2 metres are mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to gov.uk foreign travel advice, public transportation is operating however only up to half capacity of the vehicle is allowed. The destination must be reached before the start of curfew hours. Exit and entry into the Windhoek-Okahandja-Rehoboth Local Authority Area is restricted – except for returning residents, essential service providers in possession of the relevant permit, emergency medical cases and transport of human remains for burial.    https://archive.vn/GKnmG

According to gov.uk, until July 15, public transport operators will not be permitted to travel between regions, including long-haul operators and aircraft. Within regions, operators may only carry passengers to half the capacity of the vehicle. Public health measures, such as wearing a face mask, must be adhered to when using public transport, for the duration of the journey, and the destination must be reached before the start of curfew hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, starting June 16, 2021, a nationwide curfew is in place from 10 PM to 4 AM. Vulnerable populations are recommended to stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, there is a nationwide curfew from 9 pm to 4 am daily, with no movement allowed during those hours. These regulations are in place until July 15.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, starting June 16, 2021, restrictions are in place for travel into and out of the city, such as in Okahandja and Rehoboth. Returning residents are allowed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, until July 15, no travel is permitted between all regions across the country – except for returning residents, essential service providers in possession of the relevant permit, emergency medical cases and transport of human remains for burial, who will be permitted entry and exit with the relevant permit. Special dispensation is in place for tourists. Furthermore, public transport operators will not be permitted to travel between regions, including long-haul operators and aircraft. Within regions, operators may only carry passengers to half the capacity of the vehicle. Public health measures, such as wearing a face mask, must be adhered to when using public transport, for the duration of the journey, and the destination must be reached before the start of curfew hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia,as of June 16, 2021, most land borders are closed for tourism purposes (Only Katima Mulilo, Ariamsvlei, and Noordoewer border posts and Walvis Bay Harbor can be used for tourist entries by land and sea), however commercial flights are operating. Travelers must present a negative COVID PCR test result no older than 7 days. Non-Namibian travelers arriving with a negative result that is older than 7 days will be placed in quarantine and tested for COVID-19 on the same day at their own cost.  If the results of this test come back negative, they will be released from quarantine.  If positive, they will be isolated at their own cost, according to Namibia’s isolation protocols.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to gov.uk, airports and sea ports are open, however some land borders remain closed. Entrants are required to present a negative PCR test result no older than 7 days. Entrants may be tested 7 days after arrival. Permanent residents are not required to show a negative result, but would then be required to quarantine for 7 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704064538/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/entry-requirements

No changes. Persons who may have been exposed are asked to contact the Health Ministry for direction.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210619014255/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There is continued evidence of contact tracing. In a New Era article from June 28, 2021, Omaheke regional director of health Jeremia Shikulo remarked, ""We continue with surveillance, contact tracing and testing, risk communication, community engagement and awareness raising, the isolation/quarantine of confirmed and suspected cases, the provision of psychosocial support to patients, staff members and bereaved families, the monitoring and supervision of Covid-19 burials, recruitment of health professionals, and the acquisition of personal protective equipment, medical equipment, medical supplies as well as the Covid-19 vaccination campaign.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704070134/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106280614.html
Masks are still required all times in public places, including on public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
According to gov.uk, public face masks are still required in public spaces at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704063103/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/namibia/coronavirus

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, as of June 16, 2021, the vaccine is available to anyone who falls within Namibia's eligibility guidelines, which includes healthcare workers and clinically vulnerable populations. (A, B) Namibia has placed age restrictions on vaccines and includes the elderly as part of the eligible group (C). The available vaccines are Covishield and Sinovax.    According to Namibian Minister of Health and Social Services Kalumbi Shangula, Namibia has made progress in its preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines.  The government has paid to acquire enough vaccine doses to vaccine 20% of the population through the COVAX Facility.  Namibia has begun vaccinating targeted populations with donated vaccines from China, and plans to roll out additional donated vaccines from India soon.  Namibia is prioritizing frontline health care workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19.  Minister Shangula also announced that non-Namibian citizens can receive a vaccine in Namibia if they fall into one of the designated priority groups eligible for the vaccine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Namibia has used AstraZeneca (Covishield) and Sinopharm vaccines, however supplies are running low according to Reuters. The government is prioritizing those who have received a first dose, which were previously available to all groups. New first doses have been suspended by the Health Ministry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210704070202/https://www.reuters.com/world/us/namibia-suspend-first-doses-covid-19-vaccine-supplies-run-low-memo-2021-06-26/

Country-Specific Information    Nigeria is experiencing a reduction in COVID-19 cases.  Basic services (i.e., grocery stores, gas stations, transportation etc.) are available in Nigeria, and schools have resumed.  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited.  Religious events are limited to 50% of the capacity of the facility. Social distancing and mask wearing are required.  Effective May 4, the Presidential Steering Committee on COVID-19 instituted additional protocols for passengers originating from Brazil, India, and Turkey.      See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210614151204/https://ng.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

For travel from all other countries, prior to departure, passengers travelling to Nigeria must complete the on-line pre-boarding health declaration at the Nigeria International Travel Portal. They must also have tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of their departure to Nigeria, and have uploaded their PCR test certificate to the on-line Travel Portal. Passengers must also carry evidence of the test and result when they travel. Only a COVID-19 PCR test is acceptable to the Nigerian authorities. Also before travel, passengers must book and pay for a repeat PCR test for day 7 of their arrival in Nigeria at the Nigeria International Travel Portal– evidence of the booking will be required on arrival. On arrival all passengers will be screened by Port Health Officials and be required to provide full contact details, including their address in Nigeria.    The Nigerian government has said it will closely monitor whether passengers are following the quarantine measures and conducting the repeat PCR test. On 21 December, the Federal Government announced that it would impose sanctions on travellers to Nigeria who fail to take the repeat PCR test on day 7.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Quarantine requirements  All new arrivals are expected to self-isolate at one location in the city of their arrival until the result of their second PCR test (which should be taken on day 7 of arrival) is known. If the second test is negative individuals can exit self-isolation from day 8 onwards. Anyone that has developed symptoms of coronavirus during their travel or later tests positive will be managed according to national guidelines for COVID-19 treatment. This may require quarantine at a government-monitored treatment centre.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524152228/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/entry-requirements

The Federal Government has relaxed the lockdown restrictions in place in Abuja and Lagos and replaced them with new requirements, including a nationwide daily night time curfew between midnight and 4am and the mandatory use of face masks in public.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210614153542/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

Public spaces and services  Gatherings of over 50 people outside of work places are prohibited, including all weddings, conferences and sporting events. Bars, restaurants other than in hotels, events and recreational centres are currently closed. Places of worship are permitted to hold services, subject to limitations set by state authorities.    Visits to public institutions, including government buildings, have been limited.    Additional measures include a mandatory requirement to wear face masks in public spaces.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621163406/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

A national vaccination programme was launched on 5 March. Health workers (and other front line staff) will be prioritised in the first phase. This will be followed by phase 2 (people aged 50 and above) and phase 3 (people with co-morbidities).    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210614153542/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus    But at the same time the vaccine is available for some other groups

COVID-19 vaccines if you live in Nigeria  Wherever possible British nationals living in Nigeria should aim to be vaccinated in Nigeria. You should seek advice from your healthcare provider on the availability of vaccines locally. You can also obtain further information from National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA) or contact individual State Health authorities who will be responsible for the vaccine roll out in each State.    A national vaccination programme was launched on 5 March. Health workers (and other front line staff) will be prioritised in the first phase. This will be followed by phase 2 (people aged 50 and above) and phase 3 (people with co-morbidities).    The vaccine registration e-portal is now open on the NPHCDA website. Nigerians and residents of Nigeria will be eligible according to priority. You should upload your National Identity Number (NIN), passport or other forms of ID as advised on the portal in order to register. You can get further information on registration from the NPHCDA on 00 234 (0) 803 123 0415/0416.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621163406/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

Attendance at a wake/vigil (Ikiriyo) should not exceed 10 persons at any one time. Funeral gatherings should not exceed 30 persons.  Civil and religious weddings should not exceed 30 persons.  Traditional weddings and related receptions shall resume not exceeding 30 persons. However, when conducted in hotels/entertainment venues or open gardens they should not exceed 30% of venue capacity and COVID-19 testing will be required.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615084833/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/rwanda/coronavirus

Arriving passengers at Kigali International airport must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to first departure. Negative test certificates must include the term ‘PCR’. COVID-19 testing is not mandatory for accompanied children under 5 years. All passengers must complete the passenger locator form and upload the COVID-19 test certificate before heading to the airport. All passengers will be screened upon entry.    All passengers arriving from India are required to complete 7 days in mandatory quarantine upon arrival at a designated hotel at their own cost.  Entry at land borders remains restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210615084845/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/rwanda/entry-requirements

International travelAs of May 6, international passengers arriving and departing Kigali International Airport (KGL) must present a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken within 72 hours prior to departure. Arriving travelers may be forced to take a PCR test and quarantine at a designated hotel for 24 hours while waiting for the result. Authorities also announced that all passengers arriving from India will be subject to a 7-day quarantine at a designated hotel at their expense.    web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475446/rwanda-authorities-update-select-covid-19-restrictions-from-may-6-through-may-31-update-21

RBC offers rapid antigen testing without appointment at 42 accredited private hospitals/clinics throughout Rwanda. Rapid antigen tests cost $10. Rapid antigen test results are available shortly after the sample is taken and are delivered in person. Available at 45 private hospitals.

The Somali authorities at the national and local level (excluding Somaliland) have put in place a range of measures to control the spread of COVID-19. In Mogadishu, these include a night-time curfew, as well as measures relating to public gatherings, schools and mosques. The Somaliland authorities issued measures to control the spread of COVID-19 on 22 March 2021. The measures include: Wearing of facemasks in all public and private spaces, including at mosques and public gatherings; Social distancing of 2 metres (1.5 metres in mosques); Installation and use of hand washing and sanitising equipment; Avoidance of public gatherings. Where public gatherings do take place they must be well ventilated and attendees must wear masks, socially distance and wash hands; Closure of sports centres, gyms and playgrounds; Additional measures at mosques.     https://archive.vn/7o7iq

Curfew is in place in Somalia. Everyone is encouraged to avoid gatherings and adhere to COVID-19 prevention measures such as wearing masks and practising social distancing.      https://archive.vn/iBqON

Public transportation is operating normally. Passengers are encouraged to wear masks when using public vehicles. There is a USD 5 fine for non-compliance with existing social distancing guidance, movement restrictions, mask mandates, etc.     https://archive.vn/iBqON

Curfew is in place in Somalia. Everyone is encouraged to avoid gatherings and adhere to COVID-19 prevention measures such as wearing masks and practising social distancing.      https://archive.vn/iBqON
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.     https://archive.vn/iBqON

A negative COVID-19 test(PCR and/or serology) is taken within 96 hours of travel is required to enter Somalia. Passengers leaving the country must have a negative COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours of travel. Passengers are required to arrive at the border checkpoint at least three hours before departure to have time to implement health and safety procedures. In Somaliland, you will not need to quarantine if you have evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken within 96 hours before arrival. There are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.     https://archive.vn/iBqON

COVID-19 surveillance in South Sudan is operated by the South Sudan Ministry of Health (MOH) with support from implementing partners. The surveillance system collected testing and case data from five sources:† 1) screening of inbound travelers at points of entry, 2) rapid response team testing of persons with COVID-19–compatible symptoms who called an alert hotline (alert), 3) contact tracing, 4) testing of symptomatic persons seeking health care for any reason (sentinel surveillance), and 5) screening of persons before outbound travel (travel screening).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606193220/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7022a3.htm

According to the UNESCO, all schools are open: https://web.archive.org/web/20210628070919/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse  COVID -19 screening is ongoing in all health facilities and schools to identify suspect cases: https://web.archive.org/web/20210628073731/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/ESWATINI_COVID-19-SITREP_-29.05.2021.pdf
From 14 June 2021, all retailers will be shut after 7pm.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071409/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/coronavirus

Gatherings remain prohibited except for funerals, community meetings, weddings, professional low-contact sports and religious services. Gatherings are limited to 2.5 hours, with a maximum of 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071409/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/coronavirus

Gatherings remain prohibited except for funerals, community meetings, weddings, professional low-contact sports and religious services. Gatherings are limited to 2.5 hours, with a maximum of 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071409/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/coronavirus

•	Is public transportation operating? Yes.  •	Passengers are required to wear masks and use hand sanitizer upon entry into the vehicle.  •	Passengers are required to wear masks and use hand sanitizer upon entry into the vehicle. Passenger limit is at 80% capacity both public and private vehicles.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071211/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
•	Is a curfew in place? Yes. Non essential traveling between 8PM and 4AM is prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071211/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

•	Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are roadblocks between cities where temperatures are checked.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071211/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Specific conditions must be met in order to enter Eswatini:  •	A COVID-19 test must be performed no more than 72 hours before departure and you must be able to demonstrate a negative test result on entry  •	Upon arriving in Eswatini, you will be screened for COVID-19 symptoms and asked about your country of origin and any transit stops  •	If you do not present a negative COVID-19 result on entry, or if you display COVID-19 symptoms, you will be required to take a COVID-19 test on arrival at your own cost  •	You may be required to undergo a quarantine period not exceeding 14 days, or isolation as advised by the port health officers  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/entry-requirements

The government has set up a revolving fund of E45 million (0.07 percent of GDP) to assist SMEs, and a E25 million (0.04 percent of GDP) relief fund to aid laid off workers, E12.8 million of which has been disbursed to laid off workers thus far. https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071737/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Revenue measures to mitigate the impact of the virus include: (i) taxpayers projecting losses will file loss provisional returns and no payment will be required; (ii) extension of returns filing deadlines by 3 months before penalties kick-in; (iii) payment arrangements for taxpayers facing cash flow problems; (iv) waiver of penalties and interest for older tax debts if principal is cleared by the end of September 2020; and (v) up to E90 million (0.13 percent of GDP) in tax refunds for SMEs that have complied with tax obligations, retain employees, and continue to pay them during this period. https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071737/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Government website and social media: https://web.archive.org/web/20210628072709/https://translate.googleapis.com/translate_static/css/translateelement.css

COVID-19 Testing:  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Eswatini? Yes.  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  •	For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  •	U.S. citizens can receive COVID testing at clinics and hospitals within the country. The cost is generally $50. Results are available for pickup in 24 – 48 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071211/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information

Government will continue to capacitate the health sector to ensure that testing, contact tracing, isolation, quarantine and quality care continue parallel to this vaccination programme  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628075914/https://reliefweb.int/report/eswatini/eswatini-launches-nationwide-covid-19-vaccination-campaign
It is compulsory to wear a mask everywhere, even when travelling alone in a vehicle.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628071409/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/coronavirus

"" Since March 25, 2021, most travelers are permitted to enter Seychelles with a negative COVID-19 PCR test result submitted before departure and proof of accommodation for the duration of stay. Visitors with physical presence in Bangladesh, Brazil, India, Nepal, Pakistan, and South Africa within the 14 days preceding arrival are not permitted entry. ""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614161951/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/

No change since last week:  ""In April 2020, the government has announced a measure - The Financial Assistance for Job Retention (FA4JR) program – to subsidize wages for companies facing distress caused by COVID-19. From July, Seychelles Employee Transition Scheme (SETS) was set up to facilitate the reskilling and placement in an economic activity of persons made redundant as a result of COVID-19. This program works alongside the wage subsidy to aid the transition to a post-COVID economy.""  https://archive.ph/Yv0cT#selection-20915.0-20915.463

No change since last week:  ""Clients of the Home Finance Company (HFC) and the Property Management Corporation (PMC) will benefit from a 25 percent support on their loan repayments between Sep 1, 2020 and Dec 31, 2021; from Sep 10, Small Business Support Fund (SBSF) facility was launched, which will provide interest-free loans to small businesses""  https://archive.ph/Yv0cT

Stays longer than 7 days you are required to quarantine, visits shorter than 7 days you do not have to quarantine.    ----  https://web.archive.org/web/20210620165343/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523162931/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/africa/chad  https://web.archive.org/web/20210620162705/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210620165408/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad

Travellers planning to stay in Chad for 7 days or more are required to surrender their passport, quarantine at home for 7 days and take a Covid-19 test on the 7th day. There is no need to quarantine if travellers are staying in Chad for less than 7 days. All travellers from the UK are banned from entering.  ----  https://web.archive.org/web/20210630070138/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/entry-requirements

The Tanzanian government has not released aggregate numbers on COVID-19 cases or deaths since April 2020. The use of masks, social distancing, and other prevention strategies are largely absent throughout Tanzania.  https://archive.ph/2m2Gy#selection-2965.0-2965.214

No evidence of closures per IMF, US Embassy or Tanzanian government sources. https://web.archive.org/web/20210630014308/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629051927/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of May 4, 2021, all flights to and from India are banned in Tanzania with limited exceptions.  https://archive.ph/2m2Gy#selection-2995.0-2995.96  Targeted quarantine for passengers from India   All travelers arriving from India or having traveled through India in the last 14 days will be subjected to a rapid test at the Point of Entry followed by 14-days mandatory quarantine at their own cost.  Travelers subject to mandatory quarantine shall choose a place from the list designated by the Tanzanian government, which is available at airports.  Returning residents from India will be allowed to quarantine in their homes under a strict surveillance system.  https://archive.ph/2m2Gy#selection-3261.0-3273.111

Travellers must provide a negative PCR test within 48 hours, and must quarantine if arriving from certain countries like India with a widespread variant.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629051927/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Government of Uganda recommends that all travellers from the United States (and all Category 2 countries, which also include the United Kingdom, UAE, Turkey, South Africa, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania) postpone any non-essential travel to Uganda.    Any traveler from the Category 2 countries, including the United States, will be subjected to a PCR COVID-19 test, at the traveler’s expense, at all points of entry into Uganda, including Entebbe International Airport.  These travellers will have to wait for their negative results before proceeding to their final destination in Uganda.    Individuals who have received a full COVID-19 vaccination and are asymptomatic will be allowed into Uganda without the need for testing on arrival.  Such travellers will need to show evidence of their vaccination.    The Ministry of Health requires that COVID-19 tests be taken at an approved facility within 120 hours.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531115312/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/

Schools are open with precautionary measures in place. Primary school students and students with special needs will return to the traditional format on July 26 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613213829/https://www.gov.za/speeches/basic-education-issues-directions-%C2%A0date-return-all-learners-primary-schools-29-may-2021

Schools must comply with social distancing and health and safety measures, with all learners in primary schools will return to daily attendance from 26 July 2021. Teaching and learning may be conducted outside the confines of a classroom provided that all safety measures are observed. Contact sports in schools are temporarily suspended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001405/https://www.gov.za/speeches/basic-education-issues-directions-%C2%A0date-return-all-learners-primary-schools-29-may-2021

Schools and institutions of higher education will be closed for contact classes from 30 June 2021. Early childhood development centres will remain open.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021,  many retail shops and services, supermarkets, pharmacies, and businesses continue to operate in line with safety protocols, but will be strictly enforcing mask rules.    The government is asking businesses to allow workers to stay home where possible under Alert Level 2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223825/https://www.gov.za/coronavirus/alert-level-2

Under Alert level 3, working from home is recommended but not required, with the exception of specific sectors such as night clubs. Working outside the home is subject to health protocols and social distancing measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

All persons who are able to work from home must do so. However, persons will be permitted to perform any type of work outside the home, and to travel to and from work and for work purposes under Adjusted Alert Level 4, subject to-  (a) strict adherence to health protocols and social distancing measures;  (b) the return to work being phased-in in order to put in place measures to make the workplace COVID-19 ready;  (c) the return to work being done in a manner that avoids and reduces risks of infection; and  (d) the work not being listed under the specific exclusions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, public gatherings are allowed with attendance restrictions. Outdoor events are allowed up to 250 people and indoor events are allowed up to 100 people. COVID-19 health and safety protocols must continue to be followed at all times, including observance of guidelines for social distancing of 2 meters, sanitation and hygiene, and use of appropriate personal protective equipment, like cloth face masks, as determined by the South African National Department of Health. Sporting events are permitted with restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223825/https://www.gov.za/coronavirus/alert-level-2#gatherings

Events such as conferences, entertainments and protests are restricted to 50 or less persons for indoor venues and 100 or less for outdoor venues. Sport matches only allow the necessary employees, without any spectator being allowed on the venue.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

Any place or premises normally open to the public where religious, cultural, entertainment, recreational, or similar activities take place is closed and prohibited in terms of these regulations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, public gatherings are allowed with attendance restrictions. Outdoor events are allowed up to 250 people and indoor events are allowed up to 100 people. COVID-19 health and safety protocols must continue to be followed at all times, including observance of guidelines for social distancing of 2 meters, sanitation and hygiene, and use of appropriate personal protective equipment, like cloth face masks, as determined by the South African National Department of Health. Sporting events are permitted with restrictions.    No more than 50% capacity of a venue can be exceeded in any case outside of hotel accommodation as outlined by Alert Level 2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223825/https://www.gov.za/coronavirus/alert-level-2#gatherings

Since 16 June 2021, gatherings are restricted to 50 persons or less for indoor venues, and 100 persons or less for outdoor venues.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

All gatherings are prohibited, except-  (a) for funerals (limited to 50 people);  (b) when at a workplace; or  (c) when buying or obtaining goods and services.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, public transportation is operating at a reduced level with health measures.    Public rail, minibus taxi, and bus services have resumed at reduced levels subject to social distancing and mandatory use of face masks for passengers and drivers. Minibus taxis and buses must reduce their maximum licensed passenger seating capacity to 70% a vehicle, e-hailing services that are licensed to carry up to four passengers are limited to carrying 50% of their permissible passenger carrying capacity. Transport services are required to provide adequate sanitizers for washing of hands of all passengers. Operators must ensure that their vehicles are sanitized before picking up and after dropping off passengers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Public transport is available but restricted. Bus and taxi services’ capacity is reduced to 70 percent of the licensed capacity for long distance travel (200km or more).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

Bus and taxi services-  (a) may not carry more than 70 percent of the licensed capacity for long distance travel (200 km); and  (b) may carry 100 percent of the licensed capacity for any trip not regarded as long distance travel in terms of subregulation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, a nationwide curfew exists from 11:00 PM to 4 AM.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Since 16 June 2021, every person is confined to their place of residence under curfew from 10PM to 4AM, with few exceptions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

Every person is confined to his or her place of residence from 21H00 until 04H00 daily, unless a person-  (a) has been granted permission through directions issued by the relevant Cabinet member or a permit to perform a service;  (b) is attending to a security or medical emergency; or  (c) arrives on a flight or is travelling to or from an airport which necessitates travelling during restricted hours of movement: Provided that the person traveling is in possession of a valid boarding pass as proof of flight or a copy of the airline ticket.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, domestic air travel is operating alongside public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Since 16 June 2021, under Alert level 3, travel between provinces is prohibited, with few exceptions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001736/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/individuals-and-households/travel-coronavirus-covid-19

Interprovincial travel is prohibited with few exceptions under alert level 4.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, travelers are screened at airports and required to present a negative COVID result within 72 hours of departure time. Quarantine is only required for those who do not meet the testing requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Upon arrival into South Africa, all travellers must present a negative PCR or Covid-19 test certificate not older than 72 hours from departure time from the country of origin. In the event of the traveller's failure to to submit a valid negative test, the traveller will be required to do an antigen test. In the event of a positive test, the traveller will be required to quarantine for 10 days at their own cost.  https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/individuals-and-households/travel-coronavirus-covid-19

There are 20 land borders in operation and 33 land borders remain closed. All daily commuters from neighbouring countries are subject to COVID-19 screening.  International air travel is restricted to some airports. All international travellers   (a) must provide a valid certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, recognised by the World Health Organisation, which was obtained not more than 72 hours before the date of travel.  (d) In the event of the traveller's failure to submit a certificate as proof of a negative COVID-19 test, the traveller will be required to do an antigen test on arrival at his or her own cost and in the event of a traveller testing positive for COVID-19, he or she will be required to isolate him or herself at his or her own cost, for a period of 10 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools
No income support past April 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032704/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy change has occurred. COVID-19 Social Relief of Distress (SRD) grants amounting to R350 are offered to those unemployed and not receiving unemployment benefits.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001954/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/individuals-and-households/social-grants-coronavirus-covid-19

No policy change has occurred. COVID-19 Social Relief of Distress (SRD) grants amounting to R350 are offered to those unemployed and not receiving unemployment benefits.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705150725/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/individuals-and-households/social-grants-coronavirus-covid-19
There are continued protections against eviction without court order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223825/https://www.gov.za/coronavirus/alert-level-2

Relief from eviction from own land/home and demolition of place of residence is granted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622001546/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

A person may not be evicted from his or her land or home or have his or her place of residence demolished for the duration of the national state of disaster unless a competent court has granted an order authorising the eviction or demolition.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210523172657/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/disaster-management-act-regulations-alert-level-4-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown#schools

Updates are being provided on the government website and on the government social media accounts such as Twitter.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223030/https://www.gov.za/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210611153949/https://twitter.com/GovernmentZA
Public information campaign on COVID-19 is coordinated through the government website and social media accounts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622002052/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/
All information on COVID-19 and related measures is available at official government websites.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705151018/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, PCR testing is widely available at cost of the patient.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

The National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) recommends that hospitalised patients, in addition to anyone who displays symptoms of COVID-19, and individuals who are close contacts of confirmed cases should be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621234053/https://www.nicd.ac.za/diseases-a-z-index/covid-19/frequently-asked-questions/

The following categories of people should be tested in both the public and private health sectors:  Hospitalised patients  Any person with symptoms where COVID-19 infection is considered to be a possible cause.  Individuals who are close contacts of confirmed cases, including asymptomatic contacts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705151413/https://www.nicd.ac.za/diseases-a-z-index/covid-19/frequently-asked-questions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219214301/https://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Updated-Prioritised-Covid-19-Testing-Guidance-Oct-2020.pdf

Statement by the Premier of KZN, Hon. Mr Sihle Zikalala remarked on June 6, 2021 that South Africa is testing all contacts of confirmed cases. There is also a mobile app being used called COVID Alert South Africa.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613222858/https://www.gov.za/speeches/premier-sihle-zikalala-media-briefing-latest-developments-regarding-coronavirus-covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613223223/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covidalert/

The mobile app COVID Alert SA, launched in September 2020, notifies all individuals who have been in contact with someone who has tested positive in the past 14 days anonymously.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621234644/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/2020/09/01/department-of-health-launches-powerful-new-tool-to-strengthen-covid-19-contact-tracing/

National Guidelines for case-finding, diagnosis, and public health response in South Africa reference contact tracing:  ""Every effort should be made to initiate contact tracing within 24 hours of notification of a positive test.  • Contact tracing has been decentralised to provincial or district level.  • Some provinces are implementing electronic tools and information technology (such as the Telkom Track and  Trace, or the DHIS contact tracing tool)  The National Indicator Data set (NIDS) for COVID-19 contact tracing includes: proportion of contacts seen, proportion  of contacts lost to follow-up, proportion of contacts who become suspect cases, proportion of contacts who become  known cases and proportion of new cases who are known contacts.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705152259/https://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/NICD_DoH-COVID-19-Guidelines_Final_3-Jul-2020.pdf

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, masks are required in all public places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613195451/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

In phase 2 of the vaccination rollout, the vaccine is being offered to essential workers, persons older than 60 years old, and adults over 18 with co-morbidities.  https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.gov.za/covid-19/about/alert-level-3-during-coronavirus-covid-19-lockdown

""Cloth masks can be used when you are out in public. Like when you are travelling to work on public transport or doing shopping.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210608101638/https://www.nicd.ac.za/diseases-a-z-index/covid-19/advice-for-the-public/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-masks/

According to the U.S. Embassy in South Africa, as of June 1, 2021, South Africa has Pfizer and Johnson&Johnson vaccines available. In phase 2 of the vaccination rollout, the vaccine is being offered to essential workers, persons older than 60 years old, and adults over 18 with co-morbidities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621235702/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/vaccine-updates/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618114516/https://vaccine.enroll.health.gov.za/

""A, B, C""  South Africa is currently in their second phase of the vaccine rollout which is intended for people over 60, people over 18 with co-morbidities, essential workers and people in congregate settings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705154500/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/latest-vaccine-statistics/

Zambia on Friday reintroduced the COVID-19 test on arrival and the mandatory 14-day quarantine for travellers from 15 countries.    According to a joint statement from the Health Ministry and Public Health Institute in the capital Lusaka, the affected countries are    India, Iran, Turkey, France, Germany, Russia, Brazil, Argentina, South Africa, Egypt, Tunisia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Italy and Tanzania. The ministry said the list would be reviewed and updated regularly.    Otherwise international travel screening remains in place. A negative PCR test is required within 72 hours before departure to Zambia. Limited screening is in place at Lusaka airport which involves temperature checks as well as antigen tests if required. Symptomatic passengers may be asked to self-isolate for 14 days. No exit requirements are demanded by the Zambian government though airlines and destination countries may have their own health requirements.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210607185654/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Zambia has implemented limited screening upon arrival at the international airport in Lusaka.  The screening entails completing COVID-19 risk assessment form and may include using no-touch thermometers (“thermo-scanners”) to check body temperature.   Symptomatic individuals will be required to self-isolate for 14 days and may be asked to submit samples for additional COVID-19 testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617012051/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Arrivals from high risk countries are required to quarantine for 14 days. Other arrivals must also quarantine if a valid negative test is not produced, or if not vaccinated.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621155217/https://zm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/
